abstracts.cdata!:
The Forestry Project for Cameroon was
            plagued with problems throughout. Loan effectiveness was
            delayed, and a fire destroyed the bleaching chemical plant
            in the pulp mill in 1982. Also, external markets of pine and
            eucalyptus were poor. The Bank dropped the pulpwood
            plantation component and cancelled part of the loan in 1984.
            Other plantation components made little progress during the
            first two years of the project. Senior managerial changes, a
            weak technical assistance team, and a shortage of operating
            funds were among other problems. The Government proposed a
            re-designed project which was accepted by the Bank in 1985.
            However, in spite of the apparent will of the project
            management and the Bank to make the project work, the
            physical results since 1986 have also been problematic. Poor
            soils and fire damage afflicted the new woodlots. The
            national economy cannot continue to sustain public sector
            parastatals involved in the types of activities supported by
            this project. The Bank supervised the project as the
            situation warranted, although it emphasized recruitment
            while neglecting to plan for fire protection. The Borrower
            was supportive but did not fulfill its commitment to provide
            adequate funds. The primary lesson learned is that the
            project designers failed to support and encourage tree
            planting by the private sector when it concentrated on
            Government plantations. Other lessons include: (a) the
            number of agencies involved in a project needs to be kept to
            a minimum and progress must be closely monitored throughout;
            (b) when the pulpwood plantation was dropped and other
            components made little progress, the project should have
            been re-appraised or closed; (c) a project should not depend
            too strongly on technical assistance and the Government
            needs to be involved in project design and execution; and
            (d) the risks of fire in the arid zone plantations need to
            be adequately dealt with in implementation.
